name: The Edgewater Hotel Seattle

reviews.text: I stayed at the Edgewater for the weekend on a business trip. I got the room for $99/night on Priceline. For $99 in Seattle...it is hard to say anything bad about the place.
reviews.title: Great shower & bath products! Didn't love the location.

likes.disliked: — The location at the bottom of the hill.

reviews.text: The valet parking is $31.89/night with in and out privileges. The guys were pretty quick. There is a nice fireplace and Starbucks cart while you are waiting.
reviews.title: Nice view, surreal breakfast, noisy trains

reviews.text: The rooms and bathrooms are very roomy. The best thing about the hotels are the showers (note: no bathtubs.) The rain showers are terrific. The bath products are huge, brightly colored and smell great. I would certainly rate them in my top 10 of "hotel bath amenities." There is lots of counter space in the bathroom. It also includes one of the good magnifying mirrors. There is also a large closet in the bathroom with nice hangers.
reviews.title: Rustic, Almost Elegant On-The-Water Experience

reviews.text: The beds are firms and the linens are fine. There is a cute sitting area with two comfy chairs and a fireplace. The balcony is small, but cute.
reviews.title: A bit below average... unfortunately

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed November 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The front of the hotel does face a highway and a train track. The train is quite loud. If you are a light sleeper...I recommend bringing earplugs. During the weekend i was there, it was $90/night more for a room facing the water.
reviews.title: Cosy lodge

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed March 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Stayed last weekend at the Edgewater after winning a $100/night bid on Priceline. FOR THE PRICE, it was a great deal.
reviews.title: Great deal (at a discount)

reviews.text: Location: Right on the waterfront. Was about a 5-10 minute walk to the Ferry Terminal and Pike Place.
reviews.title: Not a family place

reviews.text: Parking: $28/night. Yikes. Valets were fairly quick and very courteous.
reviews.title: Loved it! Very cozy

reviews.text: Check-in: Efficient. Got offered an upgrade to a larger, waterside room for $50/night more. We passed as we weren't spending much time in the hotel anyway.
reviews.title: Quaint Hotel

reviews.text: Room: Very small. Like tiny small. We were on the city side. From what we saw from the hallways, the rooms on the water side were bigger. The fireplace was nice, but the room would get hot fast since it was so small. The temperature was a little tricky to regulate. The bed was very soft ( a little too soft for me). The bathroom was very nice. It looked very new. The shower was nice, but I wish it had a real door. They did provide free starbucks and tazo teas in the room, that was a very nice touch.
reviews.title: Great experience at the Edgewater

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed March 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Booked on Priceline, very last minute, in fact the night before! Offered $100/night and it was accepted. I did upgrade by calling the hotel direct in the morning for an additional $20/night for a larger King room on the 3rd floor - City View. It's true the train goes by quite a bit, but it's expected as the hotel is built right on a pier, so it's an industrial, but very clean area. I would say it's more tourist than industrial though. Great location, only 15 min walk to Pike Place Market, Downtown shopping, Space Center, etc.
reviews.title: Pleasant but a bit noisy

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed March 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Room was clean and "lodge" like, which we found to be very charming. There was a nice balcony which we sat out at, even as cold as it was and drank our coffee (Starbucks) which was provided in the room, as well as Tazo teas. The bathroom was big and new with granite countertop and big glass encased shower with a "rain" shower head. In the corner of the room was a fireplace which would turn on when the room got below 68 degrees as well as two comfy armchairs and a "hairy" ottoman. There was also a desk with additional reading lamp. The bathroom ammenities were very nice, from their brand spa (Noble House), but there was no spa at the hotel.
reviews.title: The view is spectacular, but.....

likes.disliked: — The price, and the music in the Lounge

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed March 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The Bad - uncomfortable bed - like a rock, compared to other hotels with their heavenly beds....We ordered room service once in the morning and it came late and cold. We ate one meal at the restaurant - breakfast, and it was ok. The walls are thin, so we kept our voices down and the tv volume to a minimum and luckily our neighbors did as well. Unfortunately one night for a couple of hours, there were some guests that decided to have a party on our floor in the hallway. Security responded quickly, but had to come up several times. Parking is another issue, although convenient, $28 + tax per night - OUCH!
reviews.title: Wow, what a surprise!

likes.disliked: — sometimes the seagulls outside our window were loud - no big deal though!

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed September 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The Good - nice room, nice view, great location, great service. Go to Anthony's at Pier 66 for a wonderful dinner and check out their diner downstairs for casual dining. Both have an outdoor patio.
reviews.title: Ideal location, nice room

likes.disliked: — Expected more from this highly rated hotel

reviews.text: Having lived in Washington my entire life I was well aware of the Edgewater hotel and it's reputation. Having never had the opportunity to stay there I was very excited to have the chance to do so for my birthday. Upon arrival of the Edgewater the exterior landscaping and outdoor fireplace are very nice. The interior is literally covered in tree branches and tree trunks. Decor is very Pacific Northwest.
reviews.title: Impressed, entranced by the Edgewater

likes.liked: — Furry footrest in front of fireplace in the room.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed April 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Booked hotel for $119 on Hotwire and were upgraded to a King cityside for free. Could have upgraded to waterside for $50 but you get that view for free sitting in the lobby.
reviews.title: Nice Seattle Getaway

likes.disliked: — A touch to far from downtown core

reviews.text: I understand that parking is expensive in Seattle and all downtown hotels charge for parking, but $28 + tax for someone to park my car outside right beside the hotel is hard to swallow.
reviews.title: Great hotel, great location

reviews.text: Have no complaints about noise or room size. Breakfast in restaurant was great with a nice view. Hotel shuttle was handy.
reviews.title: Overrated!

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed December 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The Edgewater is a fine hotel built on a pier over the ocean. The magnificent lobby is built like an upscale north coast fishing lodge. That theme is carried into each guest room. We booked on Priceline and stayed Friday & Saturday night while we walked & shopped downtown. The first night we stayed in a city view room and moved the next day to an ocean view room; though the room furnishings are really no different; it was like moving to a different hotel. The ocean view is simply fabulous. Here’s my plus/minus assessment of the Edgewater.
reviews.title: Avoid Edgewater

likes.disliked: — Not clean; poor room amenities not worthy of price

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed April 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: +Great location on Alaskan Way; a 3 minute walk to the cruise ship terminal, a 5 minute walk to Pike’s Market, a 10 minute walk to the Space Needle or a 15 minute walk to the downtown shopping core.
reviews.title: Nice place but had issues with noise

description: Perched on the edge of Pier 67, The Edgewater hotel offers an easy walk to Seattle downtown vibrancy, stunning views and lodge luxury. Surround yourself with the beauty of the majestic Olympic Mountains, the sparkling waters of Elliott Bay and the velvety-pink sunsets of the Northwest sky.
